title: The Lion and the Mouse (Story 1)
author: Aesop
content: Once upon a time, in a deep jungle, a mighty lion was sleeping under the shade of a tree. A small mouse ran over his body playfully. The lion woke up angrily and caught the mouse with his huge paw. 'How dare you disturb me? I will eat you!' roared the lion. The mouse trembled and pleaded, 'Please forgive me, mighty king. One day I may be able to help you.' The lion laughed loudly at the tiny creature's courage but decided to let it go. A few days later, the lion was caught in a hunter’s net. He roared and struggled but could not escape. Hearing his cries, the little mouse came running. With his sharp teeth, the mouse nibbled at the ropes until the lion was free. The lion realized even the smallest friend can be a great helper.
moral: No act of kindness is ever wasted.

title: The Thirsty Crow (Story 2)
author: Traditional
content: On a hot summer day, a crow was flying around in search of water. After a long time, he saw a pot lying under a tree. The crow flew down eagerly and looked inside. There was a little water at the bottom, but the crow’s beak could not reach it. He thought for a while. Then he saw some pebbles nearby. One by one, he picked them up and dropped them into the pot. Slowly, the water level rose higher and higher. At last, the crow was able to drink the cool water. He felt refreshed and flew away happily.
moral: Where there is a will, there is a way.

title: Cinderella (Story 3)
author: Charles Perrault
content: Cinderella was a kind and gentle girl who lived with her wicked stepmother and two jealous stepsisters. They made her work all day, cooking, cleaning, and tending to the house, while they enjoyed luxuries. One day, an invitation came from the king to attend a royal ball. The stepsisters dressed in fine gowns and left poor Cinderella behind. She sat alone, crying, when her fairy godmother appeared. With a wave of her wand, she transformed Cinderella’s rags into a sparkling gown and gave her glass slippers. A pumpkin turned into a carriage, and mice into horses. The fairy godmother warned her, 'The magic will end at midnight.' At the ball, Cinderella captivated the prince with her beauty and grace. But at the stroke of midnight, she rushed away, leaving behind one glass slipper. The prince searched the kingdom, and when he tried the slipper on Cinderella’s foot, it fit perfectly. They married, and Cinderella’s kindness was rewarded forever.
moral: Kindness and patience can lead to happiness.

title: The Boy Who Cried Wolf (Story 4)
author: Aesop
content: A shepherd boy used to take his sheep to the hillside every day. He grew bored of watching them and thought of a trick. 'Wolf! Wolf!' he shouted, even though there was no wolf. The villagers rushed to help him, only to find it was a lie. The boy laughed at them. A few days later, he did the same again, and the villagers got angry. One evening, a real wolf came and attacked the sheep. The boy shouted desperately, 'Wolf! Wolf!' But no one came to help, thinking he was tricking them again. The wolf scattered the flock and the boy learned a hard lesson.
moral: Nobody believes a liar, even when he speaks the truth.

The villagers rushed to help him, only to find it was a lie. The boy laughed at them. A few days later, he did the same again, and the villagers got angry. One evening, a real wolf came and attacked the sheep. The boy shouted desperately, 'Wolf! Wolf!' But no one came to help, thinking he was tricking them again. The wolf scattered the flock and the boy learned a hard lesson.
moral: Nobody believes a liar, even when he speaks the truth.

title: The Lion and the Mouse (Story 41)
author: Aesop
content: Once upon a time, in a deep jungle, a mighty lion was sleeping under the shade of a tree. A small mouse ran over his body playfully. The lion woke up angrily and caught the mouse with his huge paw. 'How dare you disturb me? I will eat you!' roared the lion. The mouse trembled and pleaded, 'Please forgive me, mighty king. One day I may be able to help you.' The lion laughed loudly at the tiny creature's courage but decided to let it go. A few days later, the lion was caught in a hunter’s net. He roared and struggled but could not escape. Hearing his cries, the little mouse came running. With his sharp teeth, the mouse nibbled at the ropes until the lion was free. The lion realized even the smallest friend can be a great helper.
moral: No act of kindness is ever wasted.

title: The Thirsty Crow (Story 42)
author: Traditional
content: On a hot summer day, a crow was flying around in search of water. After a long time, he saw a pot lying under a tree. The crow flew down eagerly and looked inside. There was a little water at the bottom, but the crow’s beak could not reach it. He thought for a while. Then he saw some pebbles nearby. One by one, he picked them up and dropped them into the pot. Slowly, the water level rose higher and higher. At last, the crow was able to drink the cool water. He felt refreshed and flew away happily.
moral: Where there is a will, there is a way.

title: Cinderella (Story 43)
author: Charles Perrault
content: Cinderella was a kind and gentle girl who lived with her wicked stepmother and two jealous stepsisters. They made her work all day, cooking, cleaning, and tending to the house, while they enjoyed luxuries. One day, an invitation came from the king to attend a royal ball. The stepsisters dressed in fine gowns and left poor Cinderella behind. She sat alone, crying, when her fairy godmother appeared. With a wave of her wand, she transformed Cinderella’s rags into a sparkling gown and gave her glass slippers. A pumpkin turned into a carriage, and mice into horses. The fairy godmother warned her, 'The magic will end at midnight.' At the ball, Cinderella captivated the prince with her beauty and grace. But at the stroke of midnight, she rushed away, leaving behind one glass slipper. The prince searched the kingdom, and when he tried the slipper on Cinderella’s foot, it fit perfectly. They married, and Cinderella’s kindness was rewarded forever.
moral: Kindness and patience can lead to happiness.

author: Aesop

The villagers rushed to help him, only to find it was a lie. The boy laughed at them. A few days later, he did the same again, and the villagers got angry. One evening, a real wolf came and attacked the sheep. The boy shouted desperately, 'Wolf! Wolf!' But no one came to help, thinking he was tricking them again. The wolf scattered the flock and the boy learned a hard lesson.
moral: Nobody believes a liar, even when he speaks the truth.

One day I may be able to help you.' The lion laughed loudly at the tiny creature's courage but decided to let it go. A few days later, the lion was caught in a hunter’s net.
